urn:contentItem:6DVB-DPP3-SBKH-807C-00000-00Businesses plead for visitors as Halls Gap reopens after Grampians fire2025-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisBusinesses plead for visitors as Halls Gap reopens after Grampians fireBy Olivia Sanders, Jean Bell and Laura Mayers

The popular tourist town has been closed for 18 days as fire ripped through 76,000 thousand hectares of national park and farmland, costing businesses $1.9 million per day. 

Eighteen days after an out-of-control bushfire forced the closure of the Gariwerd/Grampians National Park, the popular tourist town of Halls Gap has reopened.

Struggling tourism operators who usually earn 25 per cent of their annual income in the three weeks after Christmas say they are desperate for visitors to return.

It is the second consecutive summer in bushfires have torn through the Grampians region in Victoria's south west, after fires in the 300-strong community of Pomonal destroyed 46 homes in February 2024.

Grampians Wimmera Mallee Tourism chief executive Marc Sleeman said the closure of Halls Gap this summer had cost businesses $1.9 million per day.

"Most businesses were preparing for a really busy period — most were only just getting on their feet after the February, March fires and the downturn in business throughout the middle of the year," he said.

"We understand there is going to be some hesitation from travellers … but Victorians are going to stand by Victorians, and I think you'll see a swell of support coming."

Long battle

Firefighters contained the fire on Monday, after it burned through 76,000 hectares of national park and farmland, destroyed four homes and 40 outbuildings, and killed more than 700 animals over three weeks.

According to Vic Emergency, there is currently no threat to communities, but visitors are being told to stay informed and monitor conditions.

Firefighters continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees and clear tracks.

Halls Gap Zoo reopened to the public on Tuesday, after being forced to evacuate its animals during the bushfires.

Owner Mark Treweek took some of the animals into his own home to ensure they were safe, while others were transported to the Ballarat or Werribee zoos.

"I'm getting back to where they're relaxed in their homes, so staff are happy they're back and everyone's nice and relaxed at the moment," Mr Treweek said.

"There's not much for businesses to keep going, so we need everyone to come back as soon as everything opens back up.

"There's still plenty to see and do so come down before the end of these holidays and keep visiting throughout the year."

Halls Gap Lakeside Tourist Park owner Josephina McDonald said she had almost 650 cancellations over the Christmas and New Year period.

She said she kept some staff on to run the park for Forest Fire Management Victoria crews.

Ms McDonald said businesses would struggle as many in Halls Gap chose not to have insurance because of the high cost.

The Victorian government said it had given 392 personal hardship assistance payments to those affected by the fires, worth about $460,000.

A spokesperson for federal Emergency Management Minister Jenny McAllister said the federal government had granted 43 disaster recovery allowance claims as of January 5, and paid almost $15,000.

Individuals and businesses have until June 23 to make claims.

Gradual reopenings

Northern Grampians Shire Council deputy mayor and Halls Gap resident and business owner Justine Hide said businesses were excited to hear more sections in the north of the park would open on Friday.

"Unfortunately, south of that, The Pinnacle area is closed but [authorities] have indicated it should open shortly," she said.

"Anyone in the regional area that can come up — even just for a day — and buy an ice cream and a picnic, go for a short walk, go to the zoo or one of our wineries … you know if you're spending your money here, you're really supporting a good bunch of humans."

Parks Victoria said other sections of the Gariwerd/Grampians National Park would reopen gradually, with MacKenzie Falls, Venus Baths and Boroka Lookout open from Friday morning.

While the Grampians Peaks Trail's northern section will reopen — the southern end was impacted by the fires.

Bookings are now open for campgrounds that are reopening on Friday.

urn:contentItem:6DV6-B0B3-S1Y5-H07X-00000-00Authorities praise efforts of crews as Grampians bushfire damage becomes clear2025-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisAuthorities praise efforts of crews as Grampians bushfire damage becomes clearPetra Oates Barry Murphy

Yarram Park Herefords was impacted by the blaze.

Authorities and locals have praised the work of fire crews in saving farmland surrounded by the Grampians National Park.

The Grampians bushfire was officially declared contained on Monday , after burning for 21 days.

Despite firefighters' best efforts, more than 13,538 hectares of farmland, including 10,053ha of pasture, was burnt, and 540 kilometres of fencing was damaged.

The well-known Yarram Park Hereford property at Willaura was one of the earlier farms to be hit by the fire after it broke out of the national park.

Yarram Park stud principal Antony Baillieu said 1200ha of land was burnt, and several kilometres of fences damaged, but there were no stock losses.

"It was going for quite a while and was still bad on Boxing Day," Mr Baillieu said.

He said his team used their own fire trucks to control the bushfire and for the most part, kept it at the farm's boundary.

"I think it's important that we do have a safe set up to defend ourselves," he said.

Rain will be needed to help the burnt 1200ha of grazing ground and forest recover.

"We haven't had a lot of rain," Mr Baillieu said.

"It'll recover with more rain but it's burnt bare.

"Nothing can graze it."

State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Heagerty praised the tireless efforts of the firefighting crews for keeping the blaze mostly contained to the national park.

"To see how tightly that fire footprint hugs the national park perimeter is an indication of the success of that work," Mr Heagerty said.

"When you look at some of the fire perimeter - where it's run out of the edge of the national park and almost comes to a screaming stop - that's because our forest fire management crews, CFA crews and the locals know how to tackle a fire when it comes out into grassland.

"That's where we generally had a high level of success of being able to slow the spread of the fire.

"When [the fire] did leave the national park, it was running into primarily agricultural land so that was a big impact for those communities, but certainly the bulk of the fire was within the national park."

With a fire footprint circumference of 422 kilometres, the fire perimeter is marked by containment lines that span from Halls Gap in the north, down to just north of Dunkeld, out west to near Moyston and contained to the fire's western edge in the middle of the Grampians National Park.

In total, more than 76,000ha of national park and agricultural land was burnt.

The fire began on December 17 after dry lightning started multiple fires in the southern part of the national park.

Preliminary data indicates livestock losses include 775 sheep, one horse, one beef cattle and 1285 beehives.

The fire claimed four residential properties in Moyston and Mafeking, and 40 outbuildings in Moyston, Willaura, Willaura North, Mafeking, Pomonal, Glenthompson and Mirranatwa.

Mr Heagerty said the rain on Monday was "the cherry on top" in containing the blaze after soaring temperatures over the weekend threatened to halt any progress in the three-week-long fire-fighting effort.

"The test was over this weekend, and because we got through the weekend without any spread of fire, that's given us the confidence to say 'okay, we've achieved the containment of this fire'," he said.

Large parts of the fire-affected area received over 10 millimetres of rain, with some sections receiving more than that.

"That rain will certainly settle things down both at the fire, but more generally, it'll give us a week of respite and a chance to recharge for all of our crews," Mr Heagerty said.

Rachel Simmonds and Nikki Reynolds

Thursday, January 30:

An evacuation warning has been extended at the Grampians, as an out of control fire moves north.

Glenisla, Hynes, Mooralla, and the eastern side of Rocklands Reservoir and Woohlpooer must leave immediately.

The bushfire in the Victoria Range at the Grampians National Park is not yet under control, and has started moving north towards Billywing Road and Glenisla.

Authorities have urged evacuees to head towards family or friends away from the warning area, or to Hamilton.

A relief centre is open at the Hamilton Performing Arts Centre, 111 Brown Street, with arrangements available for pets.

There will be a community meeting at 7pm, Thursday, at the Soldiers Memorial Hall, 2 Barker Street, Cavendish.

The fire has spread to 10,157ha near Cavendish, while the major Grampians fire remains at 76,733ha, and the Brimpaen fire is at 1454ha.

Thursday, January 30 4pm:

A fire is burning out of control at Carrathool in the NSW Riverina with 112ha burnt so far.

The NSW Fire Service initially enacted a watch and act alert for farmers and residents in the area. That was later downgraded at 3pm to advice. However, the fire was still burning out of control.

The fire is located on the Murrumbidgee River Road at Carrathool.

NSW Fire Service said the fire is continuing to spread in an easterly direction away from the township and to the north east along Wade Street. More than 30RFS firefighters were at the scene and were being assisted by two waterbombing aircraft.

Also in NSW, a separate fire at North Condobolin Road, Forbes burnt an estimated area of 13ha and was being controlled by the NSW Fire Service. At Narrabri in northern NSW a bushfire at Spring Creek Road was yet to be contained. And a large blaze at Walgett with an area of 583ha was also not yet controlled.

Thursday, January 30 9.30am:

Four fires at the Grampians continue to burn out of control, as an evacuation order has been issued for Mooralla residents.

VicEmergency issued a "leave immediately" warning for Moralla, Woohlpooer, Glenisla and Rocklands residents at 7.30am Thursday. A watch and act warning was issued for Mona Park, Strachans and Victoria Valley.

It comes as significant overnight activity caused a fire near Cavendish to spread in multiple directions, with authorities expecting it to reach private properties this morning.

Authorities closed the Henty Highway from Cavendish to Horsham, and evacuees should leave using roads headed west.

Twenty-two vehicles were responding to the fire, which had burnt nearly 8000ha. Meanwhile headed north, Wartook and surrounds were reduced to a "watch and act" after facing an evacuation warning on Wednesday. The three uncontrolled fires in the region had burnt more than 1500ha.

The major Grampians fire near Dunkeld was under control, with a combined 76,733ha burnt.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said the new fires were in remote and inaccessible areas, and they expected it to become a "campaign fire" with the five fires merging.

"Firefighters are planning to do everything in their powers to protect the communities of Wartook and Halls Gap from the progression of this fire over the coming days," he said.

Wednesday, January 29

Wartook residents have been told to evacuate to avoid the Grampians' fire spread, as it starts reaching private properties.

VicEmergency issued a warning for Wartook residents at 3.30pm on Wednesday to leave immediately, as a fire started on Mt Victory Road, Grampians National Park.

The fire started impacting private properties within half an hour.

There are six fires currently burning in the Grampians National Park, and four at the Little Desert National Park.

Dimboola residents near the Little Desert fire were able to return to their homes on Wednesday.

Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said there were winds up to 70kmh with hot temperatures before the cool change on Monday, and about 10,000 lightning strikes in Victoria.

He said the strikes paired with the existing fuel loads meant 60-70 new fire starts on private land, and 80 on public land and national parks. Six were yet to be controlled.

"The spread was incredibly fast, with rates of 14-18 kilometres an hour spread of the fire. It rapidly grew through the day to 63,000ha burnt," he said.

"Around 190 people attended the facility (Horsham Senior Citizens Centre). 27 people did stay at the facility in cars outside, a number of those with their pets. 27 people, mostly elderly, who couldn't leave Dimboola went to the hospital and sought support."

He said they were conducting an impact assessment. The Little Desert Nature Lodge was destroyed, and authorities believed two farm houses were affected.

Electricity crews needed to access and replace a burnt pole at Peronne, with 10 homes without supply.

A Powercor spokeswoman said they worked closely with emergency services to monitor ongoing fires and assess any potential effects to the network.

"There has been some minor damage to parts of the power network from a fire in the Minimay area," she said.

Meanwhile, the Bureau of Meteorology has reported a high pressure system extending cool southerly air for Victoria this week, before a high centre will pass Tasmania to Victoria on Saturday.

Daytime temperatures will reach 36 degrees at Nhill on Saturday, before peaking at 41 degrees on Sunday to Tuesday.

Willaura will reach 35 on Saturday, and 37 on Sunday and Monday.

urn:contentItem:6DNY-5DW3-RTK5-735X-00000-00Fire service levy gets rebrand2024-12-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Fire service levy gets rebrandPetra Oates

The Nationals Party has criticised the state government's decision to increase the Fire Services Property Levy.

The government announced the Fire Services Property Levy will be replaced by the new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund from July 1 next year.

The government announced the levy, which is paid for by all Victorian landowners through rates, would increase significantly in the 2024-25 state budget.

The tax hike will see Victorian ratepayers fork out an extra $60 a year on average, to fund a range of emergency services bundled together as part of a levy rebrand.

The new levy will encompass a range of state emergency services including Vic SES, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria, the CFA and Fire Rescue Victoria.

Victorian property owners will pay an additional $2.1 billion more than the old fire levy through the new levy.

Also included in the announcement was a funding package of more than $250 million for CFA and SES volunteers, and improvements to the VicEmergency app.

Member for Mildura Jade Benham called the rebrand "an insult wrapped in a cuddle".

Ms Benham said the "only positive" was that the government had announced CFA and SES volunteers would be eligible for exemptions from paying the levy.

"That's great but it's going to do nothing to increase the CFA morale," she said.

"They've kicked the CFA while they're down but at the same time said 'oh but it's okay because our CFA volunteers will be exempt from the levy'."

Member for Euroa Annabelle Cleeland said the "convoluted" announcements had been met with criticism from regional landowners and volunteer firefighters.

Ms Cleeland said CFA volunteers were concerned the increased levy would be diluted across more services and there would be less transparency on where and how money was spent.

"Labor's inability to manage core government services has resulted in the funding for the rest of our emergency services being diluted," she said.

"It sounds like a good deal but we know there are issues with Triple Zero, there are issues with our paramedics and our emergency response systems, as well as the CFA and FRV, so to bundle them all together is just going to compound a crisis, it's not fixing anything.

"And the costs once again are passed onto taxpayers."

She said the levy increase had done little to support regional CFA brigades which remained under-funded.

"No one feels happy about this announcement because no one trusts the government is actually going to be allocating sufficient money to the CFA still," she said.

"We are still waiting on the delivery of 28 of the 48 critical new heavy tankers that were promised in 2021.

"Only 15 are currently in active service, so they are great at promising things but we've never seen them come through with the goods."

A state government spokesperson said the levy increase was about improving the state's capacity to fight natural disasters.

The spokesperson said the changes meant more funding for the CFA, not less.

"This will bring Victoria's funding arrangements for emergency services into line with other states," the spokesperson said.

"Every single dollar raised will fund vital life-saving equipment, vehicles, staff, training for volunteers, community education and recovery support for when Victorians need it most."

urn:contentItem:6DMT-6SW1-JC0X-K0W9-00000-00VIC:Taxpayers slugged as state's deficit rises to $1.4b2024-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Taxpayers slugged as state's deficit rises to $1.4bMELBOURNE Dec 13

  Victorians will be slugged more in taxes as the state records an increasing budget deficit of $1.4 billion.
   The budget update was released on Friday, revealing a projected deficit of $3.6 billion in the 2024-25 financial year, due to a $1.4 billion downward revision of the net result from transactions.


   It follows increased spending on the Melbourne Metro Tunnel and a $1.5 billion injection into the state's hospitals.
   Net debt is set to reach $155.2 billion by July, dropping slightly compared to the expected $156.2 billion.
   Treasurer Tim Pallas defended the deficit, saying the state will record a surplus the year after.
   "Our economic future is secure," he told reporters on Friday.
   Mr Pallas also defended plans to raise taxes.
   "The state always cuts its cloth to meet the needs of the community," he said.
   Home owners will be hit with a doubling in the fire services levy, which Emergency Services Minister Jacyln Symes announced on Friday.
   Owners will be slugged about $60 extra a year - or $1.20 a week - under the changes, which Mr Pallas blamed on increasing challenges of fire management.
   "Climate change is real. Its practical impact upon people's wellbeing is real and our capacity to affect property in what is the most fire-prone region in the world has to be subject to constant capital by government," he said.
   Ms Symes said the SES, triple zero, Emergency Recovery Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria would benefit from the levy revenue and volunteers and long-serving ex-volunteers would be exempt.
   Electric car drivers will have to start paying more in 2026 with the government to scrap a $100 discount for electric vehicle registrations.
   The decision comes after the High Court struck down the government's EV levy in 2023.
   "It is a bit rich if we're actually incentivising them for using the roads in circumstances where they're not paying for the use of it," Mr Pallas said.
   Victoria is set to "harmonise" with Sydney and hike the congestion levy from 2026 and extend the costs into Melbourne's inner-eastern suburbs.
   This could lead to cost increases to off-street private and public car parking spaces, the budget update revealed.
   "These changes aim to reduce congestion and encourage the use of public transport by commuters to the CBD and inner-city areas," the budget update read.
   On-street parking, private car parking lots, universities and charities are among those exempt from the charges, Mr Pallas confirmed.
   "The aim here is to recognise that congestion is going to cost the Victorian economy about $10 billion a year by 2030," he said.
   Opposition Leader John Pesutto described the budget update as "annus horribilis for many businesses and Victorians".
   "It always picks off those most vulnerable - households, farmers, businesses - that are struggling to stay afloat ... and they target them because they're easy prey for a government that can't manage money," he said.

urn:contentItem:6CM9-CGF1-F0J6-J0W2-00000-00North East firefighters join the battle against Canada's rampant bushfires2024-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisNorth East firefighters join the battle against Canada's rampant bushfiresLayton Holley

A group of North East firefighters are joining the battle to contain Canada's out-of-control bushfires currently sweeping across the nation.

Firefighters Jarrod Hayes, Mathew Parker and William Bailey began their 35-day deployment in Alberta last week.

An additional 10 Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters departed on Thursday, August 1, to join the fight.

Aaron Kennedy, Hume deputy chief fire officer, said the group was well-prepared to face Canada's challenging and remote terrain, bringing specialist skills in tree-felling and dry firefighting techniques.

"Canada is experiencing some significant fires at the moment: over 400 fires across the country, more than two and a half million hectares burnt," he said.

"We can expect our firefighters will go to many of their remote, difficult fires.

"They'll be assisting in dry firefighting and tree-felling, also management of aviation and [equipment] on the ground.

"It's a great opportunity for them to use their skills."

Senior forest management officer Kirsty O'Reilly, based in Tallangatta, is embarking on her first overseas deployment and is excited about the challenge.

"There are a lot of unknowns going over there," she said. "Some of the tactics will be similar; the terrain will be similar, but the fuel will be very different.

"We have eucalypts here, whereas over there it's pine and cypress, so it burns very hot and very quickly."

Canadian-born Steve LeBrun is returning home after starting his firefighting career in the southern Rocky Mountains almost 20 years ago.

"For me, this is an amazing opportunity to go back to Canada and lead a crew of professional firefighters to help protect communities from these devastating fires," he said.

In 2019-20, Canadian firefighters supported Victorian firefighting efforts, and since then, Forest Fire Management staff have been part of multiple deployments to Canada over the past two fire seasons.

Wattle Flat resident John Breen had memories of the 1997 Creswick fire when he saw smoke billowing near his property yesterday afternoon.

"I had been keeping an eye on the app because of the fire danger. I noticed that there was a fire alert, but I couldn't see any smoke," Mr Breen said.

"All of a sudden, there was a small band of smoke coming from there; within 10 minutes, it was billowing. Someone from the CFA called in and said, 'You must leave now', which I did."

CFA trucks arrived at his property just as quickly as the fire swelled in size.

Thankfully there was minimal damage - sections of bushland on the other side of his dam had been burned with no damage to the canopy.

The damage was unlike 1997's more severe fire, which burnt most of his property but spared his house.

"When I came back it was just black, everything. All of that forest was just not a very good sight," Mr Breen said.

His neighbours gave similar stories of yesterday's fire, which flared up quickly and was met with a strong CFA response.

Liam Downes, who owns Black Cat Truffle farm and restaurant, had to evacuate his property when the fire approached.

"About 5pm, I got a call from a farmer friend; he let me know that there was a fire to the north in the bush at the back of our property," Mr Downes said.

"From there, I went to have a look, and it basically went from being a campfire to something pretty major in 10 minutes.

"We enacted our fire plan and got in the car with our dogs and animals. You kind of think you know what your fire plan is going to be until that moment. The kids are panicking, the dog doesn't want to get in."

The collection of French and English oaks at the back of the property, under which his truffles grow, were saved by the efforts of firefighters.

"They did a bloody good job.

"My brother was in the Mallacoota fires. He was camping down there and had to evacuate into the water.

"That is the time that it hit close to home. It was never something that I had dealt with personally. It is good to know that what we had in place did work."

On Tuesday, crews from Forest Fire Management Victoria used heavy machinery to clear fallen trees in the affected areas.

A few CFA units were still nearby to contain and extinguish the smouldering hot spots that remained.

Rob Turley took his bus to the Dean Recreation Reserve overnight, just in case he had to evacuate his property nearby.

Mr Turley had lived in the area during the 1997 fire and said yesterday's fire took a similar course.

"I stayed there until the last bit. I had myself set up with water. I just waited and waited," Mr Turley said.

"I didn't want to go too early because I had pumps running. If you start the pumps too early you will run out of fuel, so you have to time it right.

"Didn't have to use them, thank Christ."

The NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) will host a second community meeting at Moore Creek on Wednesday, January 1, as help arrives from Sydney to assist with the Attunga State Forest fire.

As of January 1, the fire had burned 406 hectares and is "being controlled," but it remains a concern for the RFS and residents in the surrounding area.

Moore Creek RFS hosted a bush fire information point meeting on the afternoon of Tuesday, December 31, which drew between 80 and 100 people seeking the latest information on the fire.

RFS manager for community risk for the North West Area Command, Shellie Smyth, says the second community meeting will again be held at the Moore Creek RFS station, located at 1015 Upper Moore Creek Road, Moore Creek, from 5pm on Wednesday, January 1.

"We are inviting any concerned community members from the area to come along and get an update on the fire and what strategies the RFS will be implementing in the coming days to get the fire under control," she said.

Ms Smyth said out-of-area crews, mostly from Greater Sydney, arrived in Tamworth on Tuesday afternoon to assist local RFS and Forestry Corporation crews, bringing about 100 firefighters with them.

The fresh-faced crews will strengthen control lines around the Attunga fire.

The RFS already has aviation and heavy plant crews working in the area, and advises there is no immediate threat to properties.

Residents in the area have been advised to stay alert and continue monitoring conditions closely.

Ms Smyth said the RFS would take advantage of cooler weather conditions, and weather permitting, crews would potentially conduct a number of backburns in the Attunga fire area, which would increase smoke in the Attunga and Moore Creek areas.

Unfortunately, the scattered storms that passed through the Tamworth district on New Year's Eve failed to drop a significant amount of rain on the Attunga fire ground.

Further updates A new, small fire started at Woolomin on New Year's Eve.

The Chaffey fire, on Nundle Road, Bowling Alley Point, is now contained. While it only burnt about one hectare, Ms Smyth said it had been of concern to the RFS due to its close proximity to the existing Bowling Alley Point fire, which has now burnt 37ha and is contained.

Ms Smyth said the Pudding fire on Yellow Rock Road along the Namoi River, was a "going" fire and had burned 30ha.

"We've got out-of-area crews accessing some pretty difficult terrain to try and get some containment to that fire today," she said.

"Accessibility makes this fire problematic."

The crews will be winched in to access the remote area and use hand tools and other strategies to get some containment to that fire.

The Roseneath Road fire, Watson's Creek, has now burnt 266ha. Ms Smyth said it was still "being controlled".

"Crews are working on containment lines, while the RFS has heavy plant on site today as well as crews mopping up and working on containment strategies for that fire," she said.

"The good weather conditions today give us an opportunity to get some containment today when the fire behaviour is not particularly risky."

The Warrabah Road fire, Warrabah, is contained, although it has burnt 130ha.

Ms Smyth said RFS crews will continue mopping up operations.

In the Uralla Local Government Area, the Kingstown fire on Box Forest Road has burnt 418ha but is "being controlled".

Good news Ms Smyth said the Ogunbil fire at Dungown was now at "patrol" level, having burnt 110ha.

"We will have crews just keeping an eye on it," she said.

"Crews have done an amazing job getting on top of the fire, and the RFS will continue to patrol to ensure any of trees that might still be smouldering are behaving themselves and don't cause us issues if the wind picks up or they fall over."

urn:contentItem:6DMS-X591-DY19-C1C3-00000-00Fire services levy to double as state deficit grows by $1.4bn2024-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisFire services levy to double as state deficit grows by $1.4bnKieran Rooney, Chip Le Grand

A hike in the fire services levy on rates notices will pay for other emergency services as a budget update reveals Victoria's deficit continues to climb.

Victorian property owners will be slugged with a doubling of the fire services levy as the government uses it to help pay other emergency services.

The tax hike comes as a budget update shows Victoria's deficit has grown by $1.4 billion for this financial year. Despite this, the Allan government maintains it will record an operating surplus the year after, even though it has to spend more money on the Metro Tunnel and the state's hospitals.

The fire services levy will be renamed the emergency services and volunteers fund [ESVF] and retooled to provide money towards the State Emergency Service, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Emergency Recovery Victoria.

The charge, which appears on rates notices, will grow from 8.7 cents for every $1000 of a property's capital improved value, to 17.3 cents next financial year.

The fixed cost part of the charge will also remain but will rise in line with inflation, going from $132 this year to $136 in 2025-26.

It's forecast that by 2028 this levy will collect $1.8 billion in revenue, compared to $1.033 billion collected by the fire services levy at present.

On the website outlining the changes, the government says every dollar raised would go towards "vital life-saving equipment, vehicles, staff, training for volunteers, community education, and recovery support for when Victorians need it most".

"Variable rates will be higher under the ESVF than the FSPL [fire services levy] to account for the ESVF's larger scope."

The state's mid-year budget update, released on Friday, reported Victoria's deficit, forecast in May for the 2024-25 financial year at $2.2 billion, has grown to $3.6 billion.

However, the document says the budget is still on track to record an operating surplus in 2025-26, and is forecasting a $100 million improvement with a surplus of $1.6 billion.

The report also detailed a slight change to net debt, which is now forecast to be $187.3 billion in 2028, an improvement of $500 million.

This financial year, net debt will be $155.2 billion compared to a budget forecast of $156.2 billion.

The fire levy changes came as Emergency Services Minister Jaclyn Symes announced a funding boost of more than $250 million for the Country Fire Authority and the state emergency services, including $70 million to replace trucks, tankers and pumpers.

Symes said the changes to the levy would require legislation, with the intention it would take effect by July 2025.

"I'm hoping that other political parties will see the benefit in the support that this brings to Victorians and emergency service volunteers," she said.

"Communities are asking more of their local SES volunteers than they ever have before, which is why we're giving them more funding, new trucks and the latest technology.

"Our emergency services put their lives on the line without a second thought. This package is about making sure they have what they need to keep all of us safe."

Bushfire recovery fosters community resilience and connectedness.

We had each other's backs: Bushfire recovery fosters community resilience and connectedness. Jodie Bruton reports.

Cath Davies was heavily pregnant with her first child when bushfires raged out of control in the Upper Murray five years ago.

A firefighter on maternity leave, Ms Davies watched helplessly as crews headed towards Towong to spare lives and defend property.

But once the main firefront went through Corryong, she knew exactly what she had to do.

She returned to Forest Fire Management Victoria's Corryong office to work as a radio operator.

"I didn't want to go to Albury-Wodonga because I thought being separated from the farm and the people I love would be even more stressful than staying," she recalled.

"I was worried about smoke in the air but there was smoke in Albury-Wodonga too; I kept going into work wearing a facemask every day."

The fire, which started near Walwa, burnt until mid-January and destroyed 82 homes, impacted hundreds of properties and killed more than 6000 livestock.

A week after the fire was contained, Ms Davies and husband Joel welcomed the safe arrival of their first-born child Archie.

Ms Davies said it seemed like an eternity and the blink of an eye simultaneously since the Black Summer bushfires blackened the Upper Murray landscape.

Now a mother-of-two, she said the global pandemic had also skewed time.

"The time has gone really quickly and also slow in some ways," Ms Davies said.

"It feels like yesterday and it's still very raw for some people; some haven't finished rebuilding their houses or fixing up all of their fences yet."

As deputy chairwoman of Towong Community Recovery Committee, Ms Davies said there were ample logistical and bureaucratic challenges in the weeks and months after the bushfires.

She said initially there was a revolving door of specialists leading the recovery effort.

"For the first three months the help was a bit superficial," she said.

"We'd form a relationship with one group and a month later we'd have to start again with a new group; it was tricky. Overall, house building was really slow and permits were not fast-tracked."

On the other hand, Ms Davies said the Albury-Wodonga-based Border Trust had worked hard to ensure funds met Towong Shire needs after it set up the Towong Community Bushfire Disaster Relief Fund in 2021. The fund gave $2.05 million to recovery initiatives, from community gardens and hall refurbishments to health and wellbeing programs.

"Even though we're rebuilding we also wanted to encourage resilience," Ms Davies said.

"A walking track and a new barbecue area are part of that. The Towong Hall was upgraded through bushfire recovery money; it's been the meeting place for mental health nights and lots of different functions.

"We're a closer community because of it; we used to be more disjointed and only got together once a year for the Christmas Tree but now we get together more often.

"It was reassuring to know we all had each other's backs during and after the fires."

Working for Ambulance Victoria and a decades-long CFA volunteer, Sharyn Nankervis had to put all of her efforts into Victoria State Emergency Service duties when the Black Summer bushfires hit.

Initially, only three SES volunteers were on the ground for Road Crash Rescue.

They were dispatched to the accident where volunteer firefighter Samuel McPaul, 28, died after his truck was flipped by a fire tornado in the Green Valley blaze at Jingellic. Two other Rural Fire Service Morven brigade firefighters were hurt too.

"It was really hard," she said.

"The fires were extremely devastating.

"We also lost native animals by the millions; driving around, it was black and black and black for miles.

"We knew a lot of houses had burnt but to drive around and see the houses of people we knew gone was very confronting."

When more SES crews arrived in the Upper Murray, Ms Nankervis was freed up to help with the local mail run in the early weeks and later took a lead on the bushfire recovery.

A CFA volunteer for almost 40 years, she was part of a small team that helped breathe new life into Towong Soldiers Memorial Hall over the two-year project.

Officially opened in October 2024, the 99-year-old hall was now an elegant and upgraded version of its former self and a valuable community asset.

It had a new iron roof and exterior cladding, restored pressed metal ceiling and wall panels, upgraded kitchen and new deck.

"Five years on, most people have rebuilt and farmers have replaced their fences and are getting themselves together," Ms Nankervis said.

"Towong now has some beautiful halls out of bushfire recovery money.

"This helps with community connectedness. Before the fires, people knew their immediate neighbours; now, people know so many more neighbours."

Border Trust recently shared the results of community feedback about Towong Shire's ongoing needs as part of the bushfire recovery.

The survey showed key areas needing investment included mental health and community connections; youth and education initiatives such as driving programs and career pathways; infrastructure and community spaces; sustainable recovery projects such as environmental initiatives and preventative health programs; and economic growth and tourism.

Border Trust executive officer Sue Gold said the survey highlighted the emerging needs of the Towong Shire.

"The results mirror feedback we've received via our on-the-ground community engagement and will help us prioritise projects that not only address urgent challenges but also create enduring benefits for the community," she said.

Ms Nankervis said the Towong hall was now a beautiful place to gather inside or on the deck. They hope to book functions and weddings to generate income to maintain the building.

"It was a little diamond that came out of the fires," she said. "Most people are back in their homes or have new homes. Some people did leave the area but that happened after the 2003 fires as well. People have been quiet around the anniversary but maybe they've dealt with it as much as they can for now. I like to think the majority of people are coping better now; some people will have trauma forever though."

Peter Hunt

Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has failed to defuse a ticking fire bomb of fallen trees left lying on the Wombat Forest floor since they were bowled over by June 2021 storms.

Despite calls for action, dating back to early last year, little progress has been made on clearing what recent analysis shows is about 600,000 tonnes of fallen trees, spread across 2500ha at densities ranging from 200 to 240 tonnes per hectare.

The fallen timber load across another 20,000ha of the Wombat Forest sits at close to 100t/ha, compared to undamaged forest loads of 20 to 50 tonnes per hectare.

The nation's top bushfire scientist, University of Melbourne Associate Professor Kevin Tolhurst, has warned the fallen timber risks fuelling a fire storm that would engulf nearby towns.

"That's when you see these big mushroom clouds, up to 12km high (as the fire) creates its own weather," Prof Tolhurst said.

He said normally the Wombat Forest would not be regarded as big enough to create the massive convection-driven fires that Victorians had seen on Black Saturday 2009 and during the 2019-20 summer.

"(But) with all this fallen wood you get five times as much energy resulting from every hectare, so you only need a fifth of the area to produce that convection column," Prof Tolhurst said. "It's impossible to stop."

Yet despite these warnings VicForests' attempts to clear the Wombat forest of fallen timber have been repeatedly stymied by government bureaucrats, legal action by environmental groups, protests and vandalism of contractors' heavy machinery.

Just this week the Wombat Forestcare Group lodged a summons with VicForests trying to block local firewood cutters Dale Tiley and Gary Kirby salvaging fallen trees from a 20ha site in the Wombat Forest.

Mr Tiley said they only had a quota of 4000 tonnes, which would hardly make a dent in the massive fuel load of twisted logs and debris that still lay across the forest.

But now he had no idea as to whether they could continue working on the coupe.

Wombat Forestcare convener Gayle Osborne said legal action was being taken because VicForests had failed to adequately survey the site for threatened species.

However Ms Osborne refused to make further comment until she had spoken to her barrister.

Meanwhile Mr Kirby said: "We're all just banging our heads against a brick wall", with no support from the Andrews Government.

Prof Tolhurst said it would take 40 to 50 years for the fallen timber to break down.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said "record rain over the past two years has provided challenges to safely clear storm fallen timber in Wombat Forest".

Bushfire-hit workers and sole traders can apply for 13 weeks of income support after the prime minister visited the Grampians, where a massive blaze has destroyed at least three homes. Cooler conditions have brought some relief to fire crews battling the inferno, but it could be weeks until the fire is fully extinguished given its size and the challenging mountainous terrain.

Anthony Albanese said the activation of the disaster recovery allowance would help communities get back on their feet. "This has been a devastating fire event here in the Grampians that is particularly acutely felt because of the time of year," he said while visiting Horsham, in western Victoria, yesterday.

"We live in a country which has harsh conditions. It's always had fires, it's always had these extreme weather events. But the truth is they're becoming more frequent and more intense."

The payments, which will be available from this afternoon, are for workers and sole traders directly impacted by the fire who have experienced loss of income in the local government areas of Ararat, Macedon Ranges, Northern Grampians and Southern Grampians.

Grampians Wimmera Mallee Tourism chief executive Marc Sleeman said the fires were devastating for businesses in western Victoria.

"A lot of businesses at this time of year generate 30 per cent of their income," he said. "And [the fires] are going to go on for weeks and weeks.

"People's livelihoods are at stake here. Families have also been put off over Christmas from their employer. They're going to have to start looking for other jobs because we don't know how long it's going to take to reopen the Grampians National Park."

Sleeman said there had been some close calls but, at this stage, no tourism businesses had been destroyed. "The CFA and Forest Fire Management were able to save a couple of key businesses - two that came under direct threat."

The disaster allowance has been made available alongside other support, including state and federal hardship payments as well as disaster assistance from councils.

While Sleeman thanked the prime minister for the latest round of payments, he said locals needed more from state and federal governments given the region had been hit by devastating bushfires twice in 12 months.

"We saw a 20 per cent decline in visitor spend in the six months to June as a result of the February fires. We're going to need some long-term strategies to get our visitor economy back on its feet."

As well as the three homes confirmed lost in Moyston, nearly a dozen outbuildings have been destroyed around the Grampians National Park and Macedon Ranges by the fire, which has so far scorched more than 76,000 hectares.

Premier Jacinta Allan said the number of damaged homes could rise as crews continued to assess the area.

"Part of the challenge with this Grampians fire is that it's still burning ... so where the crews can, they are in there undertaking rapid impact assessments to get a sense of property loss. So that number may go up," she said.

She expressed her support for farmers who had lost livestock, fences and other infrastructure, as well as tourism operators who would otherwise be welcoming visitors for the summer holidays.

She encouraged Victorians to remain alert to changing conditions and advice, warning the fire was still a threat.

"There's something like a 384-kilometre perimeter around this Grampians fire and on any given day, if the wind goes the wrong way, that can be an ignition point out of that perimeter," Allan said.

"We've got plenty more hot days ahead of us, so that's why crews are in there while the weather is a little bit more benign to do everything they can to suppress the most dangerous parts of the fire."

State Control Centre spokesman James Taylor said mild weather gave crews the chance to strengthen containment lines. "Crews will continue to black out the fire with help from machinery and aircraft today," he said yesterday.

The entire eastern side of the Grampians, including the towns of Halls Gap, Pomonal and Moyston, are still subject to a "watch and act" message.

Close calls for many in lead up to summer

CFA Edenhope Group deputy group officer Stuart Grigg was at the Edenhope Show with his wife and daughter at the weekend judging the shearing competition when a friend approached and told him a large bushfire was developing near his property in western Victoria.

Mr Grigg walked outside the pavilion and his worst fears were confirmed.

"I could see a great big tower of smoke from Edenhope which is about 16 kilometres away by road," he said.

"We flew home and jumped in our fire gear.

"I went into the forward command vehicle with group officer Peter Irving, who acted as a sector commander and we got to work."

Mr Grigg runs a mixed-farming operation comprising sheep, cattle and cropping about a kilometre north of the Kadnook fire shed.

The fire was about 1km from his home.

He said on arrival of the scene, firefighting conditions were challenging.

"The worst part of the fire was there were so many spot fires so you just had to deal with it as best you could," he said.

"We had 15 tankers to start with, but we ended up with 200-250 firefighters, plus Forest Fire Management Victoria crews."

The fire burnt close to 1250 hectares of land, burning mostly blue gum plantations and native forests, while one house at Kadnook was destroyed.

"I'd hate to think what would have happened if this fire had taken off in two months' time," Mr Grigg said.

'You think you know what your fire plan is going to be.'

Wattle Flat resident John Breen had memories of the 1997 Creswick fire when he saw smoke billowing near his property yesterday afternoon.

"I had been keeping an eye on the app because of the fire danger. I noticed that there was a fire alert, but I couldn't see any smoke," Mr Breen said.

"All of a sudden, there was a small band of smoke coming from there; within 10 minutes, it was billowing. Someone from the CFA called in and said, 'You must leave now', which I did."

CFA trucks arrived at his property just as quickly as the fire swelled in size.

Thankfully there was minimal damage - sections of bushland on the other side of his dam had been burned with no damage to the canopy.

The damage was unlike 1997's more severe fire, which burnt most of his property but spared his house.

"When I came back it was just black, everything. All of that forest was just not a very good sight," Mr Breen said.

His neighbours gave similar stories of yesterday's fire, which flared up quickly and was met with a strong CFA response.

Liam Downes, who owns Black Cat Truffle farm and restaurant, had to evacuate his property when the fire approached.

"About 5pm, I got a call from a farmer friend; he let me know that there was a fire to the north in the bush at the back of our property," Mr Downes said.

"From there, I went to have a look, and it basically went from being a campfire to something pretty major in 10 minutes.

"We enacted our fire plan and got in the car with our dogs and animals. You kind of think you know what your fire plan is going to be until that moment. The kids are panicking, the dog doesn't want to get in."

The collection of French and English oaks at the back of the property, under which his truffles grow, were saved by the efforts of firefighters.

"They did a bloody good job.

"My brother was in the Mallacoota fires. He was camping down there and had to evacuate into the water.

"That is the time that it hit close to home. It was never something that I had dealt with personally. It is good to know that what we had in place did work."

On Tuesday, crews from Forest Fire Management Victoria used heavy machinery to clear fallen trees in the affected areas.

A few CFA units were still nearby to contain and extinguish the smouldering hot spots that remained.

Rob Turley took his bus to the Dean Recreation Reserve overnight, just in case he had to evacuate his property nearby.

Mr Turley had lived in the area during the 1997 fire and said yesterday's fire took a similar course.

"I stayed there until the last bit. I had myself set up with water. I just waited and waited," Mr Turley said.

"I didn't want to go too early because I had pumps running. If you start the pumps too early you will run out of fuel, so you have to time it right.

"Didn't have to use them, thank Christ."

urn:contentItem:6F8J-BHJ3-S05Y-B136-00000-00AI wisdom? How does Grok 3 stack up2025-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisAI wisdom? How does Grok 3 stack upLloyd Polkinghorne,The Koondrook and Barham Bridge Newspaper

Large language models (LLMs) like the latest version of X’s Grok 3 have been shaking up the world of information gathering and academia. The ability of these programs to scour the web and gather data is undeniably impressive. But is the data accurate? Are their programs biased? And how do you get to the heart of a question?

Who could forget when Google’s AI platform Gemini couldn’t help but inject DEI (diversity, equity and inclusion) policy into historical images it was asked to create. A storm erupted when a picture of the US’s Founding Fathers replaced the historically accurate Anglo-Saxons heritage of these men with ones of African-American, Asian and Native American heritage.

I requested Grok 3 to create a picture of us having a conversation. Photo: The Koondrook and Barham Bridge Newspaper

I thought the launch of Grok 3 was a good time to test how AI is evolving. I started with some basic questions on the direction and governance of our nation. Contained among the lengthy response was a statement “Droughts, floods, and bushfires are intensifying.” Bearing in mind that these LLM’s gather data from articles, papers, posts and regurgitate it, I wanted to delve deeper.

“Are droughts, fires and floods really intensifying based on historical data?” I probed.

“Let’s dig into whether droughts, fires, and floods in Australia are truly intensifying, using historical data as our anchor. The claim gets tossed around a lot—especially with climate change in the mix—but we’ll stick to what the records say, not headlines or vibes. Here’s the breakdown, based on long-term trends up to March 2, 2025.” Replied Grok

While we have a relatively short dataset on Australia’s climatic conditions, Grok did indulge me.

Historical data demonstrated that droughts aren’t necessarily more frequent, but they’re getting more severe and prolonged in certain regions. Grok concluded not more droughts but hotter, drier ones that hit agriculture and water harder, citing an increase in temperature up 1.4°C since 1910.

Having seen the nation’s temperature rise being called into question due to a change from mercury to digital thermometers and the influence of heat sinks generated by construction, I probed deeper.

“How does the move from mercury temperature records to digital affect the temperature data?” I asked

“The shift from mercury thermometers to digital (electronic) sensors—mostly completed by the Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) in the 1990s—has sparked debate about its affect on temperature records.” replied Grok, pointing to four considerations.

Measurement differences:

Mercury thermometers, used widely pre-1990s, measure temperature via liquid expansion in glass, read manually once or twice daily (typically 9 AM and 3 PM). Digital sensors, like the platinum resistance probes in Automatic Weather Stations (AWS), record continuously, sampling every second and averaging over a minute. Mercury’s slow response smooths out fleeting spikes—say, a 30-second heat burst from a gust over asphalt. Digital sensors catch those blips, potentially pushing daily maxima up. BoM’s own tests (e.g., 2013 parallel studies) show AWS can read 0.3–0.5°C higher than mercury under identical conditions, especially on hot, windy days.

Siting and standards:

The transition overlapped with station upgrades. Pre-1990s, many mercury thermometers sat in Stevenson screens at rural sites—grass fields, less urban heat interference. AWS rollout sometimes moved sensors closer to heat sources (e.g., concrete, airports). A 2017 audit by the Australian National Audit Office flagged 20 per cent of BoM sites breaching siting guidelines—like Thredbo’s AWS near a carpark, skewing readings up. BoM insists adjustments (homogenization) fix this, but critics like Jennifer Marohasy argue the tweaks underestimate urban heat island effects, inflating trends by 0.2°C per century.

Data continuity:

BoM’s ACORN-SAT dataset, starting 1910, blends both eras, adjusting raw data to account for equipment shifts. The switch itself isn’t logged as a clean break—parallel recordings (mercury vs. AWS) ran briefly at sites like Rutherglen (1994–1996), showing AWS maxima averaging 0.4°C higher. BoM caps AWS readings at a 5-second response time to mimic mercury lag, but skeptics say this doesn’t fully bridge the gap. Result? Post-1990’s maxima likely edge higher—maybe 0.1–0.3°C—than if mercury had stayed. Trends (1.4°C warming since 1910) hold broad shape, but the rate might be slightly overstated, especially in heatwave records.

Bottom line:

The switch doesn’t “fake” warming—global datasets like NASA GISS align with BoM’s trend—but it nudges absolute temperatures up a fraction and sharpens extremes. Without unadjusted raw data (rarely public), it’s hard to pin the exact skew, but it’s not zero. Think tenths of a degree, not whole degrees.

Grok appeared quite considered in it’s response. Noting I didn’t ask about the impacts of deforestation, drying out of landscapes that could also contribute to the issue.

I did delve into bushfires more.

“How does the lack of management and traditional burn backs influence bushfires?” I asked

“The decline in fuel management—especially traditional Indigenous burning—and modern fire suppression policies have reshaped bushfire intensity. Here’s the data and logic:” replied Grok, with it’s reasoning.

Historical context:

Indigenous burn-backs, documented since pre-1788 via colonial journals and pollen records, used low-intensity fires every 2–5 years to clear undergrowth. Charcoal layers in southeast soils (e.g., Lake George) show frequent, small burns kept fuel loads at 2–4 tonnes per hectare. Post-colonization, European grazing and fire bans slashed this—by 1900, burning dropped 80 per cent in areas like Victoria’s Gippsland. Today’s eucalypt forests carry 10–30 tonnes per hectare, per CSIRO fuel assessments, 3–10 times pre-colonial levels.

Modern management:

Hazard reduction burns—controlled fires to thin fuel—aim to mimic this but fall short. In NSW, the Rural Fire Service targets 135,000 hectares annually; from 2010–2019, it averaged 120,000, just 1 per cent of public land. Victoria hit 130,000 hectares in 2023—2 per cent of forests—against a 5 per cent goal. Weather (narrow burn windows), funding (A$100 million/year vs. estimated A$300 million needed), and urban sprawl (smoke complaints) throttle efforts. Compare: Black Summer 2019–20 burned 18 million hectares—unmanaged fuel let it rip.

Fire behaviour:

Fuel load drives fire intensity. The Byram fireline intensity equation (I = H × W × R) ties heat output (I) to fuel weight (W). Double the fuel, double the energy—10 tonnes/hectare might yield 5,000 kW/m; 30 tonnes hits 15,000 kW/m, jumping from controllable to crown-fire territory. Black Saturday 2009 (15 million hectares) and Black Summer saw Forest Fire Danger Index (FFDI) values soar—100+ vs. a 1970s average of 25—partly due to drought, but heavy fuel turned dry spells into infernos. Indigenous burns kept FFDI-equivalent risk lower; explorer Thomas Mitchell noted “park-like” landscapes in 1836, rarely seen now.

Evidence:

Studies (e.g., 2020 Bushfire Royal Commission) link poor fuel management to 30–50 per cent higher fire severity. X posts from rural users—like “20 years unburnt, then boom”—echo CSIRO’s 2024 finding: unburnt sites near Sydney had 40 per cent thicker undergrowth than managed plots, doubling flame heights in tests. Suppression (putting out small fires) also builds fuel—decades of “save everything” left forests primed.

The results when I asked Grok 3 to add my beard. Photo: The Koondrook and Barham Bridge Newspaper

Bottom line:

Lack of burn-backs—traditional or modern—supercharges bushfires. Intensity’s up (50 per cent more extreme fire days since 1980s, per BoM) because fuel’s unchecked. Drought and heat set the stage, but 10–20 extra tonnes of dry scrub turn sparks into monsters. Managed burning is no cure-all—scale and climate limit it—but the data’s clear: neglect stacks the deck for bigger blazes.

Connecting the dots:

Hotter digital readings might slightly hype the drought-fire link, but the bushfire surge is more about fuel than thermometers. Both shifts—tech and land management—amplify perceptions of “intensifying” extremes, though the core drivers (warming, fuel loads) stand up to scrutiny.

It took some prompting, but we did get to some of the broader considerations of the original statement.

Having challenged the nation's direction, I turned to the joy, or lack thereof, of humanity. I probed about ancient practices of yoga, meditation and our modern values. After a few back-and-forths Grok simple stated,

“Why Not More Joyful Already? Systems aren’t built for it. Capitalism thrives on scarcity—keep people chasing, not chilling. Schools churn out workers, not feel-good masters. Pharma’s a A$50 billion industry in Australia (2024)—pills trump prana for profit. And pain’s loud—joy’s quiet, so we fixate on what screams. X posts reflect this: “World’s a mess” gets 10x the likes of “Had a great day.” Attention bias skews us grim.”

What a time to be alive!

urn:contentItem:6F1S-J7T3-RXJ6-N3R3-00000-00Firefighters make narrow escape, homes lost as state swelters2025-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisFirefighters make narrow escape, homes lost as state sweltersCassandra Morgan, Lachlan Abbott

Melbourne hit 39 degrees on Monday after three firefighters made a narrow escape when their vehicle caught alight in the Little Desert National Park.

Three firefighters have narrowly escaped after their vehicle caught alight and was destroyed in Victoria's west, as crews face a dangerous wind change and further widespread extreme heat.

The NSW firefighters were battling the Little Desert National Park fire and managed to get out of their vehicle before it was engulfed about lunchtime on Monday.

A wind change to the south on Tuesday is expected to keep fires moving in the national park. In the Grampians National Park, the wind change will threaten communities to its north, fanning flames into unburned country, authorities warned.

"What firefighters are trying to do at the moment is burn out that vegetation above those fires today and tonight, and try and take the sting out of those when the wind change comes through," Forest Fire Management Victoria chief Chris Hardman said on Monday.

"They will be very much prepared and planning for that, and doing everything they can to minimise the spread of those fires, but hot spots will show up, and it will challenge us when the wind direction changes."

Victoria was hit by hundreds of thousands of lightning strikes on Sunday, and the Bureau of Meteorology estimated about 50,000 of them reached the ground.

The lightning was to blame for many of the 114 new fires sparked on Sunday.

The Little Desert fires, two fires in the Grampians and four fires in the Great Otway National Park continued to burn on Monday.

Fire crews were confident they could secure three of the four fires in the Otways, and they would do everything they could to control the "challenging" fourth blaze, Hardman said.

Two homes and an outbuilding at Nangiloc on the NSW border were destroyed in a fire on Sunday.

"The rainfall that we have has not been widespread, and has not necessarily benefited firefighting activities," Hardman said. "In fact, small amounts of rain can make it more difficult for firefighters to do the important work that they need to do."

The State Emergency Service fielded about 950 calls for help on Sunday, about 500 of them from Geelong, where storms dumped hail and ripped the roof off at least one home.

Lara recorded 30 millimetres of rain within half an hour at one point on Sunday, while Mildura and Horsham reached a top of 43 degrees.

About 45,000 properties were without power at the peak of a widespread outage on Sunday. That number had dwindled to about 3500 by Monday afternoon.

Link to Image

Jason South

Melbourne Airport recorded a temperature of 38.6 about 3.10pm on Monday, while the mercury at Olympic Park peaked at 37.8 degrees just before 4pm, shy of the 38.5 degrees reached on Sunday afternoon. Viewbank in Melbourne's north-east tapped 39.3 degrees about 3.45pm.

Forecasters warned temperatures would remain warm overnight, and a heatwave warning is in effect until Thursday.

Tuesday would bring some relief for southern Victoria, with a cool change developing in the state's south-west in the morning and reaching Melbourne early in the afternoon, the bureau's Michael Efron said.

Tuesday would still be hot in the state's north, with temperatures in the high 30s or low 40s persisting until early Wednesday, he said.

Ambulance Victoria has responded to nine reports of children being accidentally locked in cars since Saturday, and Life Saving Victoria rescued 50 people over the weekend.

A severe thunderstorm warning was issued for heavy rainfall, damaging winds and large hailstones for parts of the south-west, Wimmera and central districts on Monday evening.

The weather bureau later warned severe thunderstorms over the south-west were likely to lead to heavy rainfall and flash flooding in the south-west overnight on Monday, including in Colac.

Heavy rainfall could also increase the risk of debris flow in fire-affected areas, and run-off could carry ash, soil, rocks and vegetation onto roads, tracks and waterways, the bureau said.

Link to Image

Jason South

"We're just starting to see some thunderstorms popping up over the west of the state, and they could produce damaging winds, heavy rainfall, as well, and also interact with fires currently in the landscape," Efron said on Monday afternoon.

"As well as that, we are looking at showers and storms again redeveloping over inland parts, in particular throughout Tuesday. We could see heavy rain, large hail and damaging winds."

Storms on Sunday rumbled from Geelong east to Melbourne, where Fire Rescue Victoria said a lightning strike was the possible cause of a house fire in Taylors Lakes.

Colac recorded wind gusts of up to 124km/h on Sunday night.

Link to Image

Nine News

The weather bureau's Blackwood station in the Wombat State Forest recorded 70 millimetres of rain in the 24 hours to 9am on Monday.

An emergency bushfire warning remains active for Mirranatwa, a farming community nestled between two ridges at the southern end of the Grampians mountain range in western Victoria.

Mirranatwa has continually been under threat since bushfires erupted in the tinder-dry Grampians in December.

First, a lightning strike on December 17 triggered a blaze in dense bushland near Yarram Gap Road that burnt 76,000 hectares and threatened Halls Gap. Emergency services said that fire was contained on January 6 after it destroyed four homes in Moyston and Mafeking, 40 outbuildings, 1285 beehives, 775 sheep, a horse and a cow.

The Bullawin Road fire in the southern Grampians is the biggest blaze still burning and the most dangerous.

It has so far burnt 30,000 hectares around the Victoria Range and has triggered several alerts for communities on the western edge of the Grampians.

Victoria's Environment Protection Authority has warned poor water quality is forecast at almost all beaches in Port Phillip Bay, rendering them not suitable for swimming as Melbourne's weather heats up.

A total fire ban has been declared for Ballarat and much of the state for Monday December 16, with the temperature predicted to hit 41C in Ballarat with strong northerly winds.

If Ballarat's temperature hits its predicted top, it will be the hottest day in five years - and the first time the temperature hit 40C in December since December 20, 2019, when it reached 43.5C.

Fire authorities have described Monday's potential fire weather as "quite horrendous" with conditions worsening throughout the day.

Weather bureau senior meteorologist Michael Efron said northerly winds would freshen to 60kmh to 70kmh, particularly over western and central districts, throughout the morning in what is "very much a classic fire weather day across Victoria".

"That will lead to extreme fire danger over those western and central parts."

The chance of thunderstorms with a gusty south westerly cool change could also trigger fires and will bring a dramatic drop in temperature of around 15C in an hour.

Country Fire Authority chief executive Jason Heffernan said the focus would be on west and south western Victoria, and certain portions of the north east.

Slightly south of Ballarat, Lake Bolac, Westmere, Streatham, Cressy, Winchelsea and surrounds are predicted to have the worst fire risk of the state.

In that area, fire conditions are likely to deteriorate to catastrophic during the day.

"The fire conditions tomorrow in those areas will be quite horrendous, those really hot, dry northerly winds ... and I wouldn't be surprised if we see, exceedance of the extreme fire danger ratings in that area," Mr Heffernan said.

"If fires do start in the landscape, they will be hard to suppress, they will spread very quickly."

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman highlighted several forest areas, including the Grampians and Wombat State Forest, as areas of particular concern.

"These are areas in the highest fire risk part of Victoria (on Monday)," he said.

Aerial firefighting helicopters are also on standby to be dispatched at the first fire call, including a Black Hawk helicopter based at Ballarat Airport.

Closer to town, Fire Rescue Victoria acting deputy commissioner Gavin Rooney issued a warning about grassfires in urban interface areas, where housing developments neighbour farmland - which includes parts of Lucas, Smythes Creek, Bonshaw, Miners Rest and other newer outer areas of Ballarat.

"Bush and grass fires do occur in rural, regional and metropolitan areas and they are dangerous," he said.

"They can move very quickly and people need to be mindful of the conditions and the environment they're in. If they are adjacent to a grassland and a fire commences, you should move two streets back and walk ...make sure you don't drive.

"If you're two or or more streets back then you should remain in position, close your doors and windows and turn off your air conditioning."

Victorian health minister Mary-Anne Thomas urged Victorians to be prepared for the scorching temperatures.

"Stay hydrated, stay indoors as much as possible and check in on loved ones," Ms Thomas said.

"With summer upon us, it is an important reminder that chronic health conditions can be exacerbated in the heat and leaving kids or animals in hot parked cars can have deadly consequences."

Extreme heat kills more people than natural disasters, but there are simple steps people can take to beat the heat:

Drink plenty of water, stay cool by seeking out air-conditioned buildings Plan ahead and schedule activities to the coolest part of the day If heading outdoors, seek shade when possible, wear a hat and sunscreen and avoid exercising in the heat Check in on others most at risk in the heat. urn:contentItem:6DN8-H4M1-JD34-V50R-00000-00Victoria on edge as 'catastrophic' conditions hit2024-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Victoria on edge as 'catastrophic' conditions hitAshleigh McMillan and Roy Ward

Most of the state will be under a total fire ban today as emergency services brace for "nasty" conditions in which temperatures for much of Victoria are forecast to soar past 40 degrees.

The Country Fire Authority is especially concerned about the state's north-east and west, where harvests are under way and conditions could become "catastrophic" in some towns in the state's west.

A top of 41 degrees is forecast for Melbourne today, with a small chance of scattered thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening, and strong, hot northerly winds of up to 50km/h. Mildura could top 46 degrees and Ouyen and Swan Hill could hit 45 degrees.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan warned that weather conditions, dry soil and "baked" fuel would make for a dangerous day. The firefighting national large air tanker was flown to Albury yesterday as a precaution.

"The 2019-2020 fire season was predicated on years of drought and we are in similar conditions in as far as soil moisture is certainly declining across much of those areas and the bush is ready to burn," Heffernan said.

"We saw that not long ago in the Chapple Vale fire in the Otways on a day of high fire danger. So I am concerned leading into Monday.

"It will be a very nasty day as far as heat is concerned, those hot northerly winds and harvest is still going because of those rains we saw a week or two ago. So harvest was postponed, which means there is still a lot of fuel out there, still a lot of activity going on.

"We want the community to do their bit as far as being prepared, as we are doing ours. It will be a nasty day, we need to make sure we are ready."

Heffernan also said western locations such as Lake Bolac, Westmere and Streatham could be "pushing to the low end of catastrophic" based on weather predictions.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said many parts of the state's forests were ready to burn.

"If you are in West Gippsland, South Gippsland and even the Mornington Peninsula, we can see that those forested areas are what we call ready to carry fire if we get an ignition source," Hardman said.

"Fire can move through those landscapes, and once you get some ignition and the wind behind it, it can become devastating very, very quickly."

Hardman said people heading away on holidays needed to stay abreast of conditions at their destination. He warned all Victorians to have multiple ways to access emergency services information in case power or mobile services went out and have fire plans ready to go.

"If there is a fire in the area you are going to, don't go there. It's better to wait until it's safe, as you can just create problems for emergency services. If there are fires in the landscape, turn around and go home."

A spokesman for the State Control Centre said it expected high temperatures in north-west Victoria.

Extreme fire danger ratings have been issued for six districts, including across Melbourne.

The Wimmera, Mallee, northern country, north-central, south-west and central districts have been given an extreme fire danger rating for today because of the potential hot, dry and windy conditions.

A total fire ban - under which no fires can be lit - has been announced for those six regions, as well as West and South Gippsland. The CFA warned people in bushfire-prone areas to be prepared to leave early.

Bureau of Meteorology senior meteorologist Lincoln Trainor said much of the state would reach a top temperature 12 to 16 degrees higher than usual.

In some parts of Victoria's south-west, temperatures are forecast to be 16 to 20 degrees hotter than usual.

Extreme fire danger on Boxing Day could turn three out-of-control Victorian bushfires into fast-moving infernos that threaten homes and lives, authorities have warned.

Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said yesterday that the forecast of near-40-degree temperatures and wind up to 100km/h meant almost all the state needed to be on high alert.

Deputy Premier Ben Carroll said the bushfire in the Grampians had grown to more than 43,000 hectares and had a 317-kilometre perimeter. "Boxing Day is going to be a big day for our state," he said.

"This is the beginning of what will be a long, hot and dangerous bushfire season."

Country Fire Authority chief officer Jason Heffernan said updated modelling for the Wimmera meant a forecast catastrophic rating had been downgraded to the upper end of the extreme level. However, all fire districts - apart from East Gippsland - now have an extreme fire danger rating on Thursday.

"The bush is dry," Heffernan said. "I've said it before, and I'll say it again: it is ready to burn."

Heffernan said he was considering a statewide total fire ban on Boxing Day and would confirm his decision today.

State Control Centre spokesman Luke Heagarty said: "This is the most significant fire danger that the state has seen - across the whole sections of the state that we're talking about - since Black Summer."

Chris Hardman, the chief fire officer at Forest Fire Management Victoria, said more than 300 firefighters and about 18 aircraft were battling the Grampians bushfire yesterday. He said planned burns were preparing defences for nearby townships such as Pomonal and Moyston as conditions worsen on Thursday and Friday.

"The communities around Dunkeld will very much be in the firing line again," he said.

Hardman said most bushfire fatalities happened when a dangerous wind change took hold, meaning firefighters were particularly concerned with reinforcing protections on the eastern flank of the Grampians fire. "But when Mother Nature decides that she's going to push fire at a rapid rate, it becomes what we call beyond suppression limits. So ... occasionally it's not possible for [firefighters] to make a difference," he said.

In the Macedon Ranges, the 144-hectare Bullengarook fire near Gisborne remains out of control and could flare up in comings days.

North of Ballarat, a fire under control near Creswick could jump containment lines and threaten the regional city's northern suburbs, Hardman warned.

On the Bass Coast, crews were using bulldozers to create a perimeter around the smaller bushfire near The Gurdies. "That fire has enormous potential to grow on Boxing Day," Hardman said.

He said temperatures in Victoria's north would be about 38 to 42 degrees and would be accompanied by hot, gusty northerly wind. "Later in the day, we expect a wind change to occur late afternoon and then the strong and gusty wind from the south-west and west. They could be up to 100km/h," he said.

Nugent said more than 100 extra firefighting resources had been called in from Tasmania, Queensland, NSW and the ACT. Eighty extra specialist firefighters would be deployed to the Grampians.

Western Victoria is bracing for increased bushfire risk this spring, as national agencies prepare resources for the coming months.

It comes as the state government's own analysis of residual fire fuel loads in the region sit 7 per cent higher than targets, with Bureau of Meteorology climatic forecasts for spring highlighting a potential early start to bushfire season through the Wimmera, Grampians National Park, and the Mallee.

The National Emergency Management Agency has flagged areas of Australia, including Victoria's far west and southwest, as particularly vulnerable to fire risk this spring, following "an unusually dry autumn and winter".

Dry winter conditions align with the Victorian government's own analysis of residual bushfire risk to the state, with the Grampians region in 2022-23 sitting at 77 per cent, 7 per cent higher than the target of 70 per cent for the region.

Forest Fire Management chief officer Chris Hardman said FFMVic had reduced bushfire risk across more than 138,000ha of public lands including the Grampians through the year, "building on the 90,000ha treated last year".

"This isn't just about a single burn or one season, it's about ongoing work we've done in the past and continue to do year round, as well as our future plans to keep protecting our communities," Mr Hardman said. "FFMVic is ready to respond with more than 3000 personnel working alongside our emergency sector partners to keep communities safe and informed about bushfire risk and how best prepare over the summer season."
